PARAL: \vd \compare\ \VARP\ 155.30cd: satyena sūryas{ }tapati somaḥ satyena rājate; \compare\ \LAKSMINARS\ 1.345.50ab: satyena sūryas{ }tapati candraḥ satyena vardhate| \compare\ \MBH\ Indeces 13.587: mucukundena māndhātrā hariścandreṇa cābhibho| satyaṃ vadata māsatyaṃ satyaṃ dharmaḥ sanātanaḥ| hariścandraś{ }carati vai divi satyena candravat||
NOTE:
ŁPāda$ a might as well be a reference to a story mentioned in \MANU\ 8.116 (although Agni normally burns the untruthful, and not the truthful): vatsasya hy abhiśastasya purā bhrātrā yavīyasā | nāgnir dadāha romāpi satyena jagataḥ spaśaḥ ||. Olivelle's note on this verse (\citeyear{OlivelleManu}, 311) reads: `Vatsa was accused by his brother of being the son of a Śūdra woman and thus not a pure Brahmin. Vatsa went through fire to prove his pedigree. See Pañcaviṃśa Brāhmana 14.6.6.'
Since Łśaśi$ (instead of Łśaśin$) is a possible stem in this text, Łśaśir ācaraḥ$ (\msNa\msNb\msNc) in Łpāda$ b could be acceptable here, perhaps standing metri causa for the compound Łśaśicaraḥ$. Nevertheless, I have chosen to conjecture Łśaśinaś caraḥ$, now preferring it to my previous conjecture, Łśaśinā caraḥ$. Other possibilities, suggested by Judit Törzsök and other colleagues, include Łśaśibhāskaraḥ$, Łśaśigocaraḥ$, Łśiśiro 'caraḥ$, and Łśiśirāmbhasaḥ$. Similar passages quoted in the apparatus suggest that the Moon vaxes, or shines, by truth (Łsatyena vardhate$/Łrājate$). Compare also a passage in the \MBH\ (quoted in the apparatus) that compares Hariścandra, renowned for his truthfulness, to the Moon, using the verb Łcarati$. These passages seem to support a reading close to my conjecture.

For Daṇḍa(ka)'s story, see \RAMAYANA\ 7.71.31 ff.: Daṇḍa meets Arajā, a beautiful girl, in a forest and rapes her. As a consequence, her father, Śukra/Bhārgava, destroyes Daṇḍa's kingdom, which thus becomes the desolate Daṇḍaka-forest.

For two versions of the destruction of Sagara's sons, who were chasing the sacrificial horse of their father's Aśvamedha sacrifice, and by doing so disturbed Kapila's meditation, and who in turn burnt them to ashes, see \MBH\ 3.105.9 ff. and \BRAHMANDAPUR\ 2.52--53.
As for Rāvaṇa's haughtiness, especially the fact that he chose to be invincible by all creatures except humans, and its consequences, one should recall the story of the \RAMAYANA\ and Rāvaṇa's destruction brought about by Rāma therein.

Saudāsa, also known as Kalmāṣapāda, hit Śakti, Vasiṣṭha's son, with a whip because the latter did not give way to him, and as a consequence Śakti cursed Saudāsa: Saudāsa had to roam the world as a Rākṣasa for twelve years. See \MBH\ 1.166.1 ff.
As for the end of the Yādavas, see the short ŁMausalaparvan$ of the \MBH\ (canto 16): cursed by the sages Viśvāmitra, Kaṇva and Nārada, and seeing menacing omens, the Yādavas take to drinking in Prabhāsa and destroy each other.
